chapter.title: Template Flags Explained
chapter.para: This documents the flags in braces at the beginning of .look file block template definitions. The flags fall into one of three classes:

listitem.para: Full, mix of multi & single line property definitions: <?template foo<= Multi line string <=foo bar=>Single line string template?>
Pipe delimited, properties are named DATA<n>, where <n> starts at 1 and increases. <?template DATA1|second arg|DATA3 template?>
One property, and it's named DATA <?template I am the DATA template?>
Static: output won't have more &bml; to expand, or properties to fill-in, so don't try.
Less static: add pRoperties, but then do not &bml; expand.

Pre-parsed. BML-expand parameters first, then interpolate into template. By default, parameters are interpolated first, then everything is expanded. But if you use %%TITLE%% twice in your PAGE, for example, and your .bml file defines TITLE=> with a _CODE block, it will be run twice, so it is generally a good idea to make PAGE definitions pre-parsed. Also, then, you avoid re-running most of your output through the &bml; expander a second time.

Expand embedded parameterless static blocks in definition early. When the template file is read, any blocks of the form are expanded ahead of time. Useful in conjunction with the {S} flag. consider: # Our image server: IMGPREFIX=>{S}http://www.site.com:8080/ # Some block that has an image: SPACER=>{Ss} The SPACER block isn't really static, but because {s} is used and (=IMGPREFIX=) is static, then SPACER can also be static.
